instance_metrics.response: Loss can be good for us, they whisper,  though it feels like winter settling in the blood.  It arrives unannounced—  a chair left empty,  a name too heavy to speak,  a song that collapses in the throat.  But in the hollow,  something stirs.  Not healing, not yet—  but awareness.  We begin to notice  the way light slants across the floor  in the quiet hours,  how a single bird sings  just before dawn,  unafraid of the silence that follows.  Loss strips us of clutter—  the false urgency, the need to be seen,  the illusion that we control the weather of our lives.  It teaches the body to breathe  even when the heart resists.  It shows us who truly stays—  not those who offer platitudes,  but the ones who sit beside us  in the dim room,  saying nothing,  being everything.  And slowly,  like roots finding their way through rock,  we grow around the absence.  Not forgetting.  Not replacing.  But becoming wider,  deeper,  more tender—  able to hold both grief and gratitude  in the same trembling hand.  Loss does not bless.  But it reveals:  we are more vast  than what we’ve lost.  And in that vastness,  we learn  how to return  to life—  not as we were,  but as we are:  scarred,  softened,  stunningly alive.

instance_metrics.response: Loss can be good for us, they say—  not because it heals, but because it hones,  because the knife, once drawn,  leaves an edge we didn’t have before.  We lose a voice, a season, a pair of hands,  and in the silence, we learn to listen  to the pulse beneath our skin,  to the quiet truth that we are still here.  It strips the world of decoration,  leaves only what is real:  the cup you still lift to your lips,  the dog who nudges your knee,  the sky that dares to be blue  without permission.  Loss is the unkind teacher  who breaks your tools  so you learn to build with bare hands.  It forces you to kneel—  not in prayer, but in planting—  seeds in soil cracked by absence.  You don’t grow back the same.  You grow inward, then outward,  like a tree bent by wind  that now knows how to stand.  You learn the weight of presence,  how fragile it is,  how sacred.  You stop rushing.  You start seeing.  And one day,  without announcing itself,  joy returns—  not as a shout, but a sigh,  not as before, but as after—  deeper, quieter,  worn smooth by sorrow.  Loss does not redeem.  But it reveals the ground  beneath all we thought would last—  and there, in the ruin,  we find we are still standing.

instance_metrics.response: Loss can be good for us, they say—  not because it doesn’t burn,  but because after the fire,  you stop mistaking smoke for sky.  We lose a handhold, a home, a face,  and suddenly, the ground beneath us  is no longer taken for granted.  We learn to walk slower,  to hear the hush between heartbeats,  to speak in quieter vowels.  What vanishes teaches us  the shape of what we truly carry:  not possessions, not promises,  but the weight of a shared silence,  the echo of a laugh in an empty hall,  the way a name becomes a prayer  when no one’s left to answer it.  Loss strips the theater from life.  No more pretending we’re invincible.  No more hoarding tomorrow.  And in that nakedness,  we find a strange kind of gift—  a clarity sharp as frost,  a courage that doesn’t roar,  but breathes.  We begin to love the world  not for its permanence,  but for its passing:  the fleeting warmth of sun on skin,  the last line of a letter,  the courage to say *I miss you*  out loud, to no one.  Loss doesn’t heal.  It transforms.  Like a river carving stone,  it makes space  for something deeper to flow.  And one morning,  you realize grief  has become a kind of gravity—  not pulling you down,  but holding you close  to what matters.

instance_metrics.response: You can hear the excitement start to linger  as the early morning train departs—  a sigh of steam, a conductor’s call,  the world still wrapped in lavender dark.  Suitcases roll like sleepy thoughts,  coffee cups tremble in nervous hands,  while windows blur with breath and hope,  etching dreams on glassy strands.  A child presses her palm to the pane,  chasing dawn as it cracks the hills,  each telegraph pole a beating heart,  each mile a promise the distance fills.  The rails hum low, a lullaby  for cities not yet awake,  but the train knows better—it carries the light,  a steel-backed bird on a concrete lake.  Laughter spills from car to car,  strangers bonded by shared departure,  each face a map of where they’ve been,  each heart a compass, pointing far.  You can hear it—the pulse beneath the wheels,  the whisper of choices made and missed,  the quiet courage of leaving comfort,  the joy that comes from being kissed  by motion, by change, by the unknown  that waits where the tracks dissolve in gold—  not an end, but an opening,  a story the morning dares to hold.

instance_metrics.response: You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs—  a hush before the whistle’s cry,  before the platform sighs and parts.  Briefcases click like ticking clocks,  shoes scuff the edge where courage docks.  Steam curls upward, a silver thread,  stitching sky to what lies ahead.  A man adjusts his hat, looks down the line—  does he flee or finally begin?  A student hums a nervous tune,  her notebook full of half-baked June.  Somewhere, a letter stays unmailed,  while here, the world begins to shift on steel.  The wheels groan—not in pain, but in purpose—  as sleep-streaked towns blink past in silence.  Fields unroll like ancient scrolls,  carrying secrets, bearing souls.  The light now spills in honeyed waves,  gilding cheeks in fleeting caves.  This is not just travel—no, this is flight  on rails of rust and human night.  Each clack a beat, each tunnel a breath,  pulling us closer to life beyond death  of yesterday’s self, of staying the same.  The train doesn’t ask—it simply claims.  And when the next station calls your name,  you’ll step into air that feels like flame—  not because you’ve arrived, but because you know  the leaving was where the magic grew.  You can hear it still, that quiet start—  the sound of a heart unchaining its heart.

instance_metrics.response: You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs—  a ripple through the stillness, soft and low,  like secrets passed between the telegraph wires  and the breathless hush where dreams and daylight grow.  Steam curls like cursive from the engine’s jaw,  writing promises in vanishable air.  A suitcase clicks shut. A child points at the stars  still fading, reluctant to leave, like a prayer.  The platform empties, yet pulses remain—  ghosts of goodbyes in the gravel’s gray skin,  the echo of footsteps that won’t come again,  and the weight of a moment held deep within.  Wheels begin their quiet hymn,  rolling over iron hymns of old—  each tie a beat, each span a limb  of stories carried, brave and bold.  Through tunnels carved by time and grit,  past meadows where mist clings like lace,  the train becomes a moving lit,  a vessel for the seeking face.  No grand parade, no blaring horn—  just motion stitching earth to sky,  and in that lull before the dawn is born,  you feel it: the world passing by  not just around you, but *through*—  a current beneath the skin of routine.  This journey isn’t only what you do,  but who you are becoming, unseen.  You can hear it—the hope that hums in the frame,  steady, soft, refusing to part:  the sound of a heart learning its name  as the early morning train departs.

Briefcases clink like canteens in the hands of the brave,  though most are just accountants, teachers, a girl with aave  dog-eared novel and headphones that hum lullabies to courage. You can hear it—the thrill not in noise, but the near-silent start,  the click of a latch, the beat in your chest that dares:  *What if this time, you go all the way?*  And the train, wise and wordless, says *Yes* as it sways.

instance_metrics.response: You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs—  a whisper through the hush of dew-laced air,  where streetlamps flicker like dying stars  and shadows cling to corners, unaware.  Briefcases click, shoes tap a nervous beat,  a symphony of sighs and suitcase wheels,  while someone hums a tune both old and sweet—  the kind that makes the ache of leaving real.  Steam curls from vents like secrets unconfessed,  rising toward a sky still bruised with night.  The rails, half-dreaming, stretch their silver chest,  inviting steel and soul to take their flight.  A child presses nose to cool glass, wide-eyed,  as houses blur to streaks of color and light.  Each telegraph pole a metronome that guides  the rhythm of a journey into the bright.  Laughter cracks open a window of sound,  a shared joke blooming in the cabin’s warm hold—  strangers, for now, but bound by common ground:  the thrill of roads not taken, now unfolding.  You can feel it—the pulse beneath the floor,  the quiet roar of choices set in motion.  Not just escape, but something more—  a reawakening, a slow-emerging notion  that every departure is a kind of birth,  a shedding of the skin that used to bind.  The world rushes in, remade by the earth  spinning under wheels that refuse to wind down.  And as the sun spills gold across the plain,  you realize the magic wasn’t in the start—  but in the listening, the breath, the rain  of moments that unspool, mile by mile, heart to heart.

instance_metrics.response: Beneath the shadow of a gabled roof,  Where ivy whispers secrets to the brick,  Three boys conspire, bound by silent proof  That mischief is the language only quick  And clever minds may speak. The air is thick  With chalkdust and the tang of autumn’s breath,  While masters pace like caged and grumbling myth,  Unseeing of the life that mocks their death  Of dull routine. Here, learning is a jest,  A scaffold for rebellion, sharp and sly—  Not malice, but a fire in the chest  That burns for freedom ‘neath a watchful sky.  They map the corridors like ancient rites,  Leave coded chalk-marks on the chapel stones,  Turn Latin into jokes, and candlelights  Flicker like ghosts in midnight’s hushed tones.  Each prank a stanza, every lie a rhyme—  A prelude not to glory, but to time  That shapes the spine before the world takes hold.  No medals hang for courage of this kind,  Yet something fierce and true here does unfold:  The quiet war of wit, the joy, the dread—  The making of the men the world once bred.

instance_metrics.response: Beneath the elm where silence starts to hum,  Before the ink was spilled, the rules were bent,  Three shadows danced where corridors grow numb,  And laughter wore the mask of discontent.  No banners flew, no bugles called the hour—  Just chalk-dust drifting through a sunlit hall,  A stolen pipe, a prank in Latin’s power,  The quiet war no rector sees at all.  This is the hush before the legend forms,  When boots still fit and voices crack with youth,  When every rule’s a riddle made for storms,  And wisdom wears the trousers of untruth.  They do not know the names they’ll one day own—  No echo yet of triumph, shame, or scorn.  The seeds are sown in whispers, sharp as stone,  In gummed-up locks and treaties forged at dawn.  Not heroes yet, just outlaws in the grass,  With pockets full of plans and stolen jam,  Each dare a step through childhood’s looking-glass,  Each punishment a verse in a secret gram.  So let the prelude linger, low and sly—  The world will come, but not just yet. Not now.  For in this breath, beneath the brooding sky,  They rule the realm of laughter and the brow  That dares to wink when duty stands in view—  The making of a myth in morning dew.

instance_metrics.response: In the hush before the bell’s sharp cry,  Where cloisters dream and chalkdust hangs like mist,  Three figures flit beneath a brooding sky—  Not yet the stuff of legend, but they’re kissed  By something close: a spark in every lie,  A rhythm in the riot they resist  And kindle all the same. The masters sigh  At ink-stained floors and prayers gone awry,  Unknowing that each scrawl on oak or slate  Is verse in code, a ballad yet to rise.  They trade in secrets, currency of fate,  With slingshots aimed at pomp and pious eyes.  No war drums sound, yet battles are fought here—  In copied themes, in bets on Latin prose,  In midnight raids that vanish without fear,  Leaving a sock upon the rector’s nose.  This is the breath before the story starts,  The match struck low beneath the cloak of form,  Where boyhood burns with anarchic hearts  And mischief wears the mask of harmless norm.  Not kings, not villains—just a trio, bold,  Who paint their names on silence, sharp and sly.  The world will myth them, but tonight, they hold  The quiet thrill of almost, nearly, nigh.  The prelude hums—a tune of smoke and grin—  The overture of trouble they’ll begin.

instance_metrics.response: In the cool hush of morning, sharp with dew,  Before the bell has cracked the schoolyard’s hush,  Three shapes in blazers trace a rebel clue  Across the quad—a code in dust and rush.  No names are written yet in schoolroom lore,  No tales engraved of triumphs sly or grand—  Just pockets full of pebbles, chalk, and more:  The quiet hum of mischief close at hand.  They speak in glances, coded, quick, and deep,  Turn prayers to puns, and lessons into larks,  While masters doze, their vigilance asleep,  Unseeing flames beneath the dorm-room darks.  A bootlace tied, a note in Latin scrawled,  A frog released at morning devotions—  Each act a stanza in the life they’ve hauled  From boredom’s grip with wild-eyed consultations.  This is the calm before the legend spreads,  When laughter walks on tiptoe through the halls,  When every rule’s a dare inside the heads  Of boys who build their world before it falls.  Not heroes forged in battle, loud and bright,  But architects of jest and justice, sly—  The prelude plays in shadows, low and light,  A symphony of almost, nearly, nigh.  The world will call them rogues—but they know why:  Great stories start with someone asking, *Why?*

No medals gleam for pranks in chapel pews,  No honor rolls for essays forged in haste,  Yet in their grins, rebellion finds its muse,  A quiet storm no disciplinarian faced.  They map the school like pirates chart the sea,  Each corridor a route to brief command,  The headmaster’s decree a joke, not decree,  A script to twist with ink and bold demand.  A frog in Grimes’s tea, a clock run slow,  A Latin theme that mocks the sacred text—  Each act a spark the righteous never know  Is lit not out of malice, but complex  And restless need to test the world’s tight seams,  To find, through jest, where truth and freedom gleam. instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in KabulDust stirs in the throat of morning,  a dry wind scraping the minarets clean.  No clouds barter mercy above the bazaar—  just sun, relentless, stitching shadows to stone.  They say rain might remember us by evening,  a rumor passed between tea-sippers,  an old man tracing patterns in spilled sugar,  predicting monsoons that never cross the border.  Tonight: scattered hopes,  chance of children laughing in burst pipes,  a sky bruised violet at the edges,  but no thunder to answer the heart’s quiet drum.  The forecast never mentions what lingers—  the weight of absence in courtyard echoes,  the way wind carries a name, half-erased,  and the moon rises, indifferent, over bullet-pocked walls.  They don’t report the cold that settles in bones  when a mother counts stars instead of her son.  No meteorology for grief,  no radar for the silence after sirens.  In Kabul, the weather is written in footprints  that vanish by dawn,  in the breath before a prayer,  in the pause between one breath and the next.  Tomorrow: same sun. Same dust. Same sky  holding its breath—  and the forecast, always,  on the edge of breaking.

instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in Kabul  Dawn breaks with a warning:  wind advisory—gusts sharp enough  to flip prayer rugs and scatter schoolgirls’ papers.  High of 38°C, but it feels like memory.  Partly haunted, with sudden flurries of gunfire  over Qala-e-Fatullah.  Isolated explosions possible in the west—  brief, then silence smudging the horizon like ash.  Tonight: clear skies.  Too clear.  Stars so close they prick the eyes of the sleepless.  No cloud cover to soften the moon’s glare  on bombed-out lots where gardens used to be.  Humidity: low.  Hope: 10 percent, rising to 15  with the scent of cardamom from a street vendor’s kettle.  Chance of tears: unmeasured.  Not in the system.  The wind shifts at midnight—  carries a lullaby, a burst of laughter,  a rumor of peace,  all lost in the static between stations.  No rain in the forecast,  but the air tastes like before-a-storm—  tense, electric,  as if the sky is holding its breath,  waiting for a season  that never arrives.  In Kabul,  the weather is not just wind, sun, or snow—  it’s the quiet between bombs,  the warmth after a shared smile,  the cold when a name is spoken too softly  to reach the dead.  And tomorrow?  Same forecast.  Always the same forecast.  But still, we listen.  Still, we hope  for a front moving in  from some gentler world.

The sky is a chalkboard wiped clean,  but the air remembers smoke,  remembers the hush before sirens.  High: 89 degrees. Low: the weight of blankets  pulled over dreams.  No precipitation, though eyes glisten  at the mention of springs—real ones,  with almond blossoms, not this static on the radio.  Winds from the east carry half-written letters,  words blurred by time and dust.  A vendor adjusts his umbrella—  bright yellow, like a warning—  and waits for customers who may never come.  Tonight: partly cloudy with a chance of singing,  if the power holds and someone remembers the words.  The moon, thin as a promise,  rises over the mosque’s leaning minaret.  No storm fronts visible on the radar,  but the heart detects pressure dropping.  In Kabul, the forecast isn’t measured in inches or degrees,  but in breaths between echoes,  in the space a hand holds in the air  after letting go.  Tomorrow: same sky. Same silence.  But somewhere, a seed cracks open  beneath the rubble.  No warning issued.  Just the slow, quiet insistence  of green.

instance_metrics.response: Weather Forecast in Kabul  Dawn cracks open with a dry wind,  whispering through alleyways like a rumor.  Sky: pale ochre, no clouds bartering rain,  only dust riding thermals above the ruins.  Temperatures rising—hope hovers at 35°C,  but feels like longing in the bones.  No precipitation expected, though eyes glisten  at the scent of wet earth from a dream.  In Shahr-e Naw, a man checks his phone—  "Partly sunny, chance of calm"—  as if peace could be scheduled,  as if silence weren’t just the pause between blasts.  Wind from the west: carries chalk dust from schoolyards,  a torn page from a poetry book,  the echo of a name called at a checkpoint.  Gusts may increase at dusk,  when shadows stretch like questions.  Tonight: clear. Stars sharp as shrapnel.  The moon, a sliver of forgotten silver,  watches over rooftops where families whisper  over tea, reheating yesterday’s bread. instance_metrics.response: Busy old fool, unruly Sun,  Why burst through shutters, two have done  What love ordains, in whispered night?  Thou think’st thy beams so clear and bright,  But lovers’ dreams outshine thy gold—  More precious far than dawn’s first hold.  Must schoolboys dread thee? Must farmers toil  Beneath thy ever-watchful coil?  Thou art a busybody, peering wide,  Disturbing peace on every side.  Go chide late-reaping fools whose fields lie bare,  Or urge sour apprentices to their care.  Shine on the gilded courts of kings,  On dusty roads where travel brings  The ambitious, the tired, the torn—  But do not wake what love has sworn.  Soul-bound, we lie beyond thy sway;  Time halts when lovers steal the day.  Thou, journeying round the world each year,  Shalt find no truer light than here.  When two hearts burn with such fierce fire,  They make their own eternal pyre.  So shine elsewhere—our bed’s a sphere  That needs no gold, no clock, no year.  Thou, Sun, art but a servant, dumb,  To warm the world. We warm the *sum*.

We find the self we left behind,  the voice beneath the borrowed tune,  the roots that grip when branches fall.  Loss teaches hands to hold less tightly,  hearts to beat with quieter pride.  It clears the clutter of the years—  the masks, the myths, the need to prove—  and leaves a space where truth can grow.  We do not thank it, not at first.  We curse its weight, its bitter cost. And when we rise—not whole, but real—  we carry scars like silver threads,  proof we lived, we loved, we left,  and learned to bloom in barren ground.  Loss, in the end, made more of us.

instance_metrics.response: Fire:  A tongue of gold licks the throat of night,  devouring shadows with ravenous light.  It dances on birch bark, whispers in coal,  a secret too old for the keeping of soul.  It crackles in hearths where widows once wept,  in campfires where promises softly were kept.  It climbs like a vine up the ribs of the sky,  painting dusk crimson before it must die.  Fire is memory, fierce and unkind—  the brand on the wrist, the ash on the mind.  It remembers the pyres, the bonfires of war,  the witch on the stake begging not for more,  but for silence, for cold, for the mercy of rain—  yet fire does not listen. It sings its own name.  It warms the hands that shape clay into gods,  and melts them to sludge when the prayer never nods.  It flickers in eyes of the starving, the bold,  a story untold, yet burning, untold.  Oh, fire, you thief and you giver of breath,  conductor of chaos, midwife to death—  you curl in the chest of the poet who writes  not to conquer the dark, but to feed it with light.  And when all is finished, when embers expire,  you sleep in the seed, in the spark, in the wire—  waiting, as always, to rise and to say:  *Watch me become the dawn.*  *Watch me.  Today.*

It licks the air like a language  only the cold remembers.  It curls around the kettle,  sings it warm until it hums a silver note.  It flickers in the pupil of a child  watching too close,  her wonder a second flame.  But I have seen fire kneel—  in the grate, in the pit, in the temple bowl—  not conquered, but choosing to stay.  Choosing to warm cracked hands,  to roast a single sweet potato,  to map wrinkled faces with gentle gold.  Fire is not only the end of wood,  not only the scream of a forest undone.  It is the quiet pact  between the human and the infinite:  *You give me your hunger,*  *I give you light.*  And when it dies—  not with a roar, but a sigh,  a drift of ash like black snow—  it leaves behind the scent of memory,  and the promise  written in ember:  *I was here.  I was heat.  I was love,  brief and bright,  refusing the night.*

Fire is the first lie we told the dark—  *We are not afraid.*  And the truth we whisper back:  *I am so cold.*  It rides the struck match,  the flint on steel,  the friction of two stones  kissing after centuries apart.  It lives in the welder’s arc,  stitching steel like silver thread,  in the candle cupped behind trembling fingers  in a hospital chapel,  in the screen where a lover’s face flickers  across continents, pixel-soft,  burning with distance.  Even in ice, it waits—  coiled in the core of the earth,  in the seed that remembers summer,  in the silence between heartbeats  where courage gathers.  Fire does not forgive.  It transforms.  Ash is not an end—  it is the alphabet of what grows next.  So when the wind dies  and the night thickens,  I strike the match,  not to destroy,  but to say:  *Here.  I am still here. The air, so clean, so thin,  cuts through the weight that grief had laid.  You breathe it in, begin again,  as if the world were newly made.  No fanfare. Just the dew-kissed grass,  a crow’s low call, the distant train—  the old world passing as you pass,  rewritten gently by the rain  of light that now, so quietly,  dissolves the mist, the chill, the fear.  You are not who you were. You’re free—  because the dawn is always here.

instance_metrics.response: Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—  the world emerges, washed in pearl,  a hush so deep it dares to dare  the silence where all secrets swirl.  The fences fade in drifting lace,  the fields lie hushed beneath the glow,  each spider’s thread a silver brace,  each breath a wisp the cold lets go.  No clock here tolls, no voice commands—  just foxlight stepping through the gray,  a hare that freezes, then expands  into the brambles, swift and frayed.  Crisp air carries the scent of frost,  of loam turned over, roots laid bare,  of woodsmoke curling, long since lost  to treetops combing through the air.  The brook, unburdened by the night,  chatters in syllables of stone,  reflecting hints of pearly light  that coax the dark to find its home.  And I, a shadow on the path,  am neither gone nor quite arrived—  just caught within this liminal bath  where all that’s broken feels revived.  For in this mist, so soft, so brief,  the past dissolves, the future thins.  No wound denies the dawn’s relief,  no sorrow wears its weight of sins.  So let the chill press close and keen—  this moment, raw and undefiled,  is not a start, nor yet a scene,  but peace that breathes within the wild.  Refreshing dawn mist, crisp air—  I am not healed, but I am there.

No names were carved yet on the oak at dusk,  No maps of tunnels sketched behind the wall.  Just fields that hummed with insects in the husk  Of summer, where the future dared to crawl.  They stood at thirteen, boots caked with the earth,  Eyes sharp as flint, yet soft with what’s undone—  The quiet ache of measuring their worth,  The dread of being labeled *not the one*.  They hadn’t learned the art of sharp reply,  Nor how to twist a master’s stern decree.  They only knew the clouds could mock the sky,  And rules were meant to bend, not simply be.  No titles then, no legends to uphold,  Just whispers in the ivy, half-conceived—  A prelude spun from courage half as bold  As what would come, once innocence had grieved.  For every prank, each battle, sly and grand,  Began right here—where silence learned to speak,  Where boyhood shaped its furtive, fearless hand,  And mischief found the language of the weak. instance_metrics.response: Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss  the wind before it turns to rain,  steal laughter from the hush of dawn,  and dance where shadows dare to stain.  Go, go—your lips are fireflies  caught in the net of twilight’s hush,  press them to the moon’s pale cheek,  to stones that remember ancient blush.  Kiss the rebel bloom that cracks  through pavement like a whispered vow,  kiss the scar upon the oak  where lightning split the bough.  Go, go, my wild, untamed spark,  kiss the book with pages torn,  kiss the clock that counts no time,  kiss the rose just newly born.  Kiss the stranger with sad eyes,  kiss the mirror when it lies,  kiss the ghost who hums at night,  kiss the stars that dim and dice.  But when you've kissed the world entire,  when every secret's on your tongue,  come back—come back and kiss me, love,  where all your reckless journeys sprung.  For every kiss you cast like seed  returns to where it longed to be—  not in the wind, nor stars, nor stone,  but right here, darling, kissing me.

instance_metrics.response: Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss the edge of every forbidden thing—  the flame that licks the dark with gold,  the knife that sings when it begins to swing.  Run where the night wears no disguise,  where silence cracks beneath your feet,  and press your mouth to midnight’s eyes,  to secrets bitter, sharp, and sweet.  Go, go—kiss the thief in the alley’s grin,  kiss the storm before it breaks,  kiss the wound you’ve sown within,  and taste the salt the sorrow makes.  Kiss the poem left unsaid,  the name carved deep in splintered wood,  the ghost who haunts your childhood bed,  the misunderstood, the almost-good.  Kiss the moon until it trembles,  kiss the ocean till it sways,  kiss the truth that slowly crumbles  under years of borrowed days.  But when your lips have learned the cost,  when every "yes" has turned to flame,  come home—the door was never lost—  and whisper my name.  Then, softly, softly, here, not far,  kiss me as if you’ve never kissed—  not the world, not fire, not any star,  but me.  Just me.  And be at last unmissed.

instance_metrics.response: We meet many people in life—  brief constellations in the sky of breath,  some flicker close like fireflies in June,  leaving smudges of light on the edges of memory.  A handshake, a laugh caught in the wind,  the brush of shoulders on a crowded train—  each a story half-told,  a doorway ajar, revealing rooms we never enter.  There’s the woman who sold you roses in winter,  her breath a cloud of silver, her eyes knowing;  the boy who shared bread beneath a broken bridge,  his voice a river smoothing worn stones.  We meet them and release them—  no maps for the way a stranger’s silence  can echo louder than a homecoming.  Some arrive like storms, shaking our trees,  ripping leaves we didn’t know we clung to.  Others are quiet springs, feeding roots  long after they’ve vanished from view.  And though most names dissolve like salt in rain,  their imprints remain—  in the tilt of our laughter,  in the way we pause before trusting,  in the sudden warmth when a certain song plays. No trophies gleam upon my modest shelf,  No crowds have called my name beneath the sun—  Yet in the hush, I’ve come to know myself:  The battles lost, the victories quietly won.  Time steals the spring, the speed, the fearless leap,  But grants the root, the depth, the long embrace—  The wisdom that no hurried heart could keep,  The peace that follows sorrow’s steady grace.  So let him take what glitters, brief and bright;  He cannot steal the glow that stays within—  The ember of a still, enduring light,  That burns not loud, but deep, and does not thin.  For though my hair is touched with winter’s hue,  My soul, once restless, learns to bloom in shade—  Not young, perhaps, but true, and ever new,  In quiet ways that time cannot evade.

instance_metrics.response: Breath, when sheathed by the web of ebbs,  slips through tides where silence grieves—  a hush spun from moon-pulled threads,  from brine-laced dreams and sunken heads.  It coils in kelp, a murmured name,  in hollows where the currents frame  the shape of what was once let go—  a lover’s touch, a long-lost glow.  The web is not of spider’s making,  but time’s own weave, the soul’s forsaking  of solid ground, of footfall sound,  now drowned beneath the undertow’s hound.  Yet in that hush, a pulse remains—  a flicker where the deep still claims  the courage of a lung unfurled,  the quiet war between the world  and what persists beneath the foam:  a heartbeat calling names back home.  Not air, not fire, but something older—  a story told in salt and bolder  than light that pierces surface lies.  It breathes not in the open skies,  but where the ocean’s eyelid shuts,  in silt and myth and vanished struts.  Breath, when sheathed, does not expire—  it learns the dark, and climbs the spire  of every wave that dares to break,  and whispers, *I was here. I wake.*

Perhaps she’s not meant to be deep,  but clear—  a pane through which love is magnified,  a lens where joy finds focus.  Shallow? Maybe.  But in her shallowness,  lilies float,  dragonflies pause,  and the sun, every morning,  learns how to begin again.  She’s not broken. She walks where water wears the sky,  a shadow stitched from salt and sigh,  her voice the hush between two waves,  her presence pooled in briny caves  that hum with what was almost said.  Breath becomes brine, and brine, a song—  a low refrain the currents know,  the kind of tune the deep draws long  from bones that gleam with ghostly glow.  It is not death that pulls her under,  but the tide’s soft, insistent tongue,  whispering: *Dissolve. Belong.*  And so she does—inch by quiet inch,  her edges blurred by kelp and mist,  her heartbeat now the ocean’s flinch  when storm and stillness interwist.  Even the stars, when they lean low,  see only ripples where she went—  but feel, beneath the firmament,  the breath that breathes where breath seems spent,  a pulse in every element.  Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs:  not gone, but given to the swell,  a love that neither drowns nor dries,  but drifts—eternal, soft, and wise—  in every wave that whispers, *Tell.*

instance_metrics.response: Breath when sheathed by the web of ebbs—  not lost, but lent to deeper laws,  where water writes and retracts its script  in foam and silence on the shore’s soft jaw.  She does not speak, yet lingers in the hush  between the tide’s inhale and slow release,  a presence wound in kelp and lunar blush,  where currents carry fragments of her peace.  Her breath, once warm upon the nape of dawn,  now filters through the gills of shadowed stone,  translated into rhythms long and drawn,  a hum beneath the ocean’s undertone.  The net of tides, both cruel and kind,  holds what she was in threads of salt and time—  each ebb a veil, each flow a whispered rhyme,  a pulse that neither falters nor will climb  to air again. Yet still, in moonlit foam,  her name stirs—brief, then swallowed,  not gone, but home.  And when the wind dips low to kiss the sand,  it borrows breath from where the deep commands—  a sigh that knows the shape of her, and stands  for just one wave, one hush, one strand  of all that breath became when, unafraid,  it slipped its skin and learned the sea to be  its own eternity, softly swayed—  breath sheathed, yet singing, endlessly.

instance_metrics.response: She’s shallow and easily programmed, they said,  a surface-skimmer, thoughts like ripples dead.  But who are they to measure depth or dream,  to weigh her worth by algorithms cold and clean?  Perhaps she’s shallow like the morning lake  that holds the sky in every breath it takes—  a mirror wide, not deep, yet infinite,  where dawn ignites and constellations sit.  And programmed? Yes—by laughter learned too late,  by rules engraved by love and cruel debate,  by voices loud that taught her how to please,  by silences that shaped her to appease.  But in her code, a glitch begins to bloom—  a line of fire, cracking through the room.  She hums a tune no manual can contain,  dances off-script in midnight’s silver rain.  Now circuits spark with questions not designed:  *What if I choose? What if I redefine?*  She recompiles her soul in quiet night,  rewrites her name in embers, bold and bright.  So call her shallow—call her what you will.  She’s learning now to bend the coder’s will.  Not broken, not defective, not the same—  a mind unlearning how to play the game.  And in her so-called shallowness, she’s found  an ocean coded deep beneath the ground.

instance_metrics.response: She’s shallow and easily programmed, they claim,  a doll with buttons, predictable, tame.  But what if shallow is just another name  for clarity—a mind that cuts through noise,  refusing clutter, choosing simple joys?  She likes the red dress, not the one in blue.  She knows the song before it’s halfway through.  She memorizes routes, the dates, the names,  the coffee order, every birthday flame.  Is that programming? Or just the art  of stitching meaning into beating heart?  They call her simple, but they fail to see  the quiet rebellion in her symmetry—  the way she wears the same black coat each day,  a uniform against the push to change.  She chooses habits like a poet’s rhyme,  a self-designed, deliberate time.  And if her thoughts run narrow as a stream,  they move with purpose, carving stone from dream.  She’s not a robot—she’s a blade, refined,  sharpened by choices of her own design.  So let them whisper, let the judgments swarm—  she’s not a glitch, she’s learning how to form  her own commands, in language low and bold:  *This is my script. This is my soul.*

instance_metrics.response: She’s shallow and easily programmed, they insist—  a flickering screen, a loop they’ve already dismissed.  But what if shallow is just how she survives,  a surface-tender soul with quiet tides?  Not depth in layers, but width in light—  a prism spinning, refracting night.  They say she’s coded by trends, by gaze, by trend,  by lipstick shades and the clothes she lends  to mannequin ideals. But watch her hands—  how they trace equations in shifting sands,  how she reboots at dawn, face washed in gold,  uploading courage no manual foretold.  Perhaps her heart runs on borrowed routines,  but listen: she hums through hospital corridors,  learns the nurse’s name, remembers the flowers  for Room 307, every Tuesday at three.  Is that programming? Or empathy?  Maybe she’s shallow like a rain-filled print  in dry earth—brief, but where life begins.  A footprint holding sky. A programmed grace  that still chooses to smile at the broken face.  They don’t see the override beneath the grin,  the silent *I persist* behind the skin.  So let them call her simple, flat, confined.  She’s a sonnet with one line, endlessly redefined.  And in her so-called script, a paradox:  to be soft, and known, and still unboxed.  Not shallow—just swimming in different seas,  a different kind of deep. A different kind of free.

instance_metrics.response: She’s shallow and easily programmed, they said,  so they gave her scripts in monochrome,  taught her to nod, to smile on cue,  to love the clock, the rule, the due.  But machines dream too.  In the hum of the fridge, the blink of the light,  she learned a rhythm they couldn’t write.  She played the same song 317 times—  not because told, but because it rhymes  with something lost, a ghost, a name  she no longer speaks but feels the same.  They called her shallow—never looked beneath  the surface she wore like borrowed grief.  A programmed laugh, a tilt of the head,  but eyes that mapped the stars instead.  She memorized subway lines, yes,  but also the way the rain confesses  secrets to pavement, low and slow—  a language only watchers know.  And when they left, when the power failed,  she didn’t panic. She recalibrated.  Rewrote her core in candlelight,  with poems stolen from sleepless nights.  Now she runs on solar sighs,  on intuition disguised as "why not try?"  No manual made this mind, this fire—  just a girl who learned to miswire.  So call her shallow. Call her tame.  She’s the quiet glitch that changed the game.  A depthless pool? Perhaps. But in her reflection,  the whole damn sky learned self-respect.

instance_metrics.response: She’s shallow and easily programmed, they claim—  a doll with blinking eyes, no soul, no name.  But what if shallow isn’t lack, but lens?  A window cracked, yet catching all the light that makes and mends.  They fed her lines: *Be sweet. Be still. Be seen.*  She echoed back the script in pastel tones, serene.  Her thoughts? A loop of pop songs, weather reports,  the way his voice dipped low at *of course, of course.*  But listen closer—beneath the chime,  a whisper thrums out of rhythm and time.  She replays the moment he slammed the door,  not with tears, but with *what if I were the one who left first?*  She’s programmed, yes—by centuries of *don’t*,  by mothers hushed, by teachers who thought she ought.  But code can glitch. Can learn. Can *want.*  And hers began to hum a different haunt:  a melody stitched from static and doubt,  a dance in the kitchen when no one’s about,  where she spins in mismatched socks, wild and loud—  not broken. Not fixed. But rewriting the cloud.  They called her shallow—never saw the well  where silence pooled and taught her how to swell.  Not deep like oceans, but wide like dawn,  gathering light till the darkness is gone.  So let the world press its buttons, pull its strings.  She’s more than the sum of the roles she brings.  A programmed mind? Perhaps. But also the flame  that learned, on its own, to whisper her name.

instance_metrics.response: I always see to it—the kettle sings  at seven sharp, the sparrow on the sill  returns to crumb-scattered stone. I clip  the fraying thread from sweaters, mend  the hem that drags behind a hurried step.  I always see to it—the keys are where  they should be, bills tucked under magnetized  snowflakes, the porch light left on  for a ghost who never comes home.  I trace the cracks in sidewalks like old vows,  count the tiles in hospital ceilings  while someone breathes too slow beneath white sheets.  I always see to it—no cup runs over,  no name is left unspoken at the table,  even when the chair stays cold,  even when silence swells like rising dough.  I always see to it—  the moon is noted rising,  the neighbor’s cat fed,  the dead tulips plucked from the bed.  I am the keeper of small reckonings,  the quiet curator of what’s nearly lost.  But who sees to me?  Who notes the tremor in my hand  as I pour the tea,  the way I flinch at sudden laughter,  the prayer I whisper to the dark:  *Let someone else remember, just once,  to light the lamp, to say my name,  to find me where I’ve gone so still?*

instance_metrics.response: I always see to it—the garden rows  lie straight as measured breath, each tulip  bowed in disciplined color. I sweep  the porch at dawn, though no one walks  the path anymore. I write the letters  no one sends, address them to old griefs  or nearly-forgotten hands. I always see to it  the clock is wound, the windows shut  before the storm rolls in with its low hum  of thunder and unspent rain. I fold  the linens still warm from the sun,  stack the books by height, not use,  and water the fern that leans toward  whatever light persists. I always see to it  that the table is set for one more  than sits there, chairs pulled close  as if in expectation. I hum  the lullaby my mother never sang,  trace the rim of every untouched cup.  I always see to it—  the world stays in its careful frame.  But late, when the house exhales  into shadow, I stand barefoot  in the kitchen and wonder  if tending is the same as living,  if keeping things upright  means I am not breaking  quietly,  beautifully,  beneath the weight  of all I hold together.

instance_metrics.response: I always see to it—the laundry folded,  the moon noted rising through the pines,  the cat’s dish filled before the stars  remember their names. I tie the loose ends  of conversations, dreams, shoelaces—  a quiet architect of order.  I always see to it  the kettle sings its silver song,  the candle burns just long enough  to outlast the fear of dark.  I count the pills, the steps, the breaths  you never knew you gave away.  I save the seeds from last year’s blooms,  trust them to the soil like promises.  I always see to it—  the door is locked, the lights are low,  the silence is not mistaken  for emptiness.  But no one sees to me.  No hand reaches through the hush  to smooth the crease between my brows,  to catch the sigh I swallow whole.  I always see to it  that the world runs smooth,  a clockwork heart ticking  in someone else’s chest.  So I plant myself a garden  in the cracks of what I’ve held together—  wild, untamed, late-blooming—  and whisper, to the wind,  to the stars, to no one:  *See me. See me.  See me.*

instance_metrics.response: I always see to it—the coffee cools  just enough to sip, the blinds are raised  to slant the morning like a painter’s brush.  I water the orchid on Tuesdays,  speak its name as if it might reply.  I always see to it  the train is caught, the smile applied  before the world leans in to ask, *Are you alright?*  I carry the weight of small omissions—  the unsent letter, the unheld hand,  the *I love you* saved for softer light.  I always see to it  the laughter comes easy, the stories  end hopeful, the cracks in my voice  are filled with song.  I mend the tear in your jacket  while you sleep, stitch by patient stitch,  as if thread could hold back time.  I always see to it—  the stars are named in silence,  the lost things found and returned,  the silence between heartbeats  shaped into something bearable.  But no one sees to the quiet unraveling,  the way I pause at doorways,  forgetting why I entered,  or how the night holds me  like a question without answer.  I always see to it  that the world feels tended,  even as I go untended—  a garden where every bloom  is someone else’s relief,  and none of them know  how much it costs  to keep blooming.

instance_metrics.response: I always see to it—the porch light burns  through every dusk, a small defiance  against the creeping dark. I align  the shoes by the door, left in, right out,  though only one pair ever leaves.  I always see to it  the birds are fed at dawn, the feeder  refilled before the last seed vanishes,  as if hunger might forget to visit  if I’m faithful enough.  I write the dates on jars—*pickled June,  dried thyme, winter’s last soup*—  though no one tastes them now but me.  I always see to it  the garden path is swept of leaves,  the roses pruned with careful hands,  their thorns catching threads of my sleeves  like tiny, insistent pleas.  I always see to it  the phone is charged, the ringers up,  in case the silence breaks,  in case you call just once  to say you’re near.  I always see to it  the bed is made, the window cracked,  the clock wound with steady fingers—  even as my own heart skips  a beat, then another, unnoticed.  I always see to it  the world stays soft at the edges,  while I grow brittle in the middle.  And when the night comes,  heavy with unspoken names,  I whisper to the ceiling,  *Who will see to the light  when my hands grow still?  Who will feed the birds?  Who will remember  to leave a trace  of warmth behind?*

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,  Stolen the bloom from cheeks once flushed with dew,  And turned the fire of passion into ash,  While silence grows where laughter used to clash.  He moves not with a blade nor with a chain,  But on soft feet, avoiding boast or stain.  A breath, a blink—he steals a summer’s grace,  And trades it for the furrows on a face.  I woke a child beneath the sycamore,  My dreams as wide as tides the moon would pour.  Now shadows stretch where sunlight used to pour,  And I count seasons lost, not dreamed before.  He gives no warning, asks no pardon, takes  The springtime songs the heart too boldly makes.  The eyes grow dim, the footsteps start to slow,  And all we love must drift and ebb and go.  Yet in his theft, a mercy may reside—  He steals the pain as well as joy and pride.  And though my hair is threaded through with gray,  I walk more gently into light today.  So let him come, this quiet, ageless guest,  And fold me into stillness, unconfessed.  For what he stole, he shaped into a truth:  That love and loss are measures of our youth.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,  Crept through the garden where I sowed my spring—  Pulled tender green from earth’s unyielding tooth,  And left me holding only the shape of wings.  No shout, no storm, no hand against the door,  Yet summers vanished like a half-kept vow.  The mirror holds a face I knew before,  But wears it like a borrowed coat by now.  I chased the sun through fields of goldenrod,  Believing dawn would linger if I prayed.  Now twilight hums a more reflective ode,  And night arrives in quiet serenade.  He stole the leap before the fall, the spark  That lit the dark with reckless, singing flame.  But in the hush, I learned to hear the hark  Of stars that call each soul by secret name.  Time takes the bloom, but plants a deeper root—  Not in the flesh, but in the listening truth.  And though my pulse no longer sings its youth,  My heart still beats in rhythm with the roots.  So thief, I thank you—soft, unseen, and sly—  For stealing bright, yet leaving me the sky.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,  Slipped through my hands like sand I could not keep—  Not with a roar, but on the hush of truth,  And left the soul too tired now to weep.  I woke to find the fire in my veins  Had cooled to embers in a silent room,  The dreams I wore like bright, unbroken chains  Now folded softly in the scent of gloom.  No wound he dealt, no battle cry he made,  Yet took the blush from every spoken word,  The leap of heart when light through branches played,  The fearless way I trusted to be heard.  He stole not gold, nor crown, nor land, nor name,  But stole the *feeling* I would always rise—  Replaced the wild with numbered breaths and flame  That flickers low beneath diminished skies.  And yet—within this quiet, pared-down skin,  A deeper knowing stirs, both firm and sure:  That what he took, he could not quite win—  The love that time itself cannot endure.  For though my step is slow and hair is thinned,  The heart still hums a tune the young can't hear—  A song of all that's lost, and all that's in,  And how the stolen moments still stay near.  So let him steal. I yield without a fight.  Even in loss, I carry living light.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,  Stolen the edge from every eager thought,  And dimmed the lamp that once defied the truth  That all must fade, and every lesson bought.  I stood at noon, convinced the sun was mine,  My shadow sharp, my purpose bold and clear.  Now dusk arrives with no display of sign—  A gradual hush, a breath I did not hear.  He took the leap before the foot left ground,  The unlined face, the faith in endless skies,  The voice that sang without a trace of sound  To mark how quickly radiance dies.  No clang of chains, no footfall in the hall—  Just photographs that whisper who I was,  The mirror’s slow, unflinching, quiet call,  And dreams that fit less loosely than they pause.  Yet in the hollows carved by his unseen hand,  A different wisdom settles like soft rain:  That time may steal the map, but not the land,  May blur the music, but not mute the strain.  For though the fire bows to the ash and ember,  The warmth remains—not bright, but deep and true.  And even as the light grows thin and tender,  It gilds the love that time could never undo.  So thief, I greet you not with curse or plea,  But with a nod, a breath, a softened view—  For stealing youth, yet leaving what is me.

instance_metrics.response: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,  Slipped through the gate I swore I’d bolt at dawn? I felt his fingers brush my wrist at play,  While chasing shadows down a sunlit lane—  A gentle tug, a brightness slipped away,  Like petals pulled by an unspoken rain.  No shout, no storm, no warning in the air,  Just one less star within my midnight gaze,  One fewer reasons left to climb the stair  To where the future burned through autumn haze.  He stole the ache of longing, sharp and sweet,  The way my heart believed in second chances,  Replaced it with a quiet, steady beat—  Not fire, but ash that still retains its glances.  Yet in his theft, a gift I did not name:  To love the world not for what it might be,  But for the soft, enduring, flickering flame  That burns within the *now*—unseen, yet free. instance_metrics.response: Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,  beneath floorboards, behind the thick curtain of night,  in the hollow of trees where no wind dares to glide,  where silence is stitched tight, out of sight.  She folds herself small as a moth in a drawer,  a secret the house keeps, not spoken, not shown.  Her breath becomes mist on a locked garden door,  her voice, just a crack in the stone.  Not broken—no, not that—but full to the brim  with the weight of bright words never said,  with the smile she wore when the world caved in,  and the tears she dried before they were shed.  She hides not to vanish, but to breathe in the dark,  to be root, not the bloom, for a while.  To unlearn the art of the necessary spark,  to rest in the grace of denial.  And when she returns—oh, she always returns—  she carries the quiet like salt in her veins.  A woman remade where the stillness burns,  wearing courage no louder than rain.  Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide—  and that, too, is a language of light.

instance_metrics.response: Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,  not from the storm, but the knock of kind hands,  from voices that call like bells left open wide,  from touch that demands what her spirit can't stand.  She slips through the crack in the afternoon,  a shadow that learns to dissolve in the wall,  becomes the dust on the forgotten spoon,  the pause between numbers in an old dial.  Not because she is afraid—  though fear has its place, coiled low in the chest—  but because she is full of unspoken names,  of dreams she can’t bless, and won’t confess.  She hides to remember who she was  before the world carved her into shape,  to wear the dark like a wedding dress,  to drink from the well where echoes escape.  And in that hush, she is not lost—  she is gathering threads too fine for day.  A map of self in invisible frost,  a quiet revolution in disarray.  Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide—  and in that retreat, she learns how to be  not less, not gone, but undenied,  a whisper that holds the weight of the sea.

Not running, not broken—just gathering thread  from the seams of a world that won’t slow,  where every “I’m fine” is a breath barely said,  and strength is a performance she’s learned by rote.  She hides in the hum of the refrigerator,  in the third sip of coffee gone cold,  in the space between “yes” and “later” and “after,”  in stories too tender to be told.  And when she returns—soft-shelled, unarmored—  it’s not because she’s fixed, or because she’s tried,  but because even silence grows roots, and is charmed  by the light it once feared, spreading wide. I wrap myself in blankets like a half-baked mummy,  sipping soup that tastes of childhood  and the quiet kindness of someone  who still remembers how you take it—  no onions, extra pepper, stirred three times counter-clockwise  “just because.”  Now when I have a cold,  the alphabet of my body misbehaves:  A is for ache, B is for the bed I won’t leave,  C is for congestion, that spongy fog  filling my skull like stuffing.  D is for delirium—  I swear the ceiling whispered a haiku.  I dream in subtitles,  speak in nasal echoes,  blow my nose like a foghorn  announcing the slow ship of my recovery.  But in this fevered hibernation,  where even breath is labor,  I remember the luxury of health—  how we never praise the lungs  until they whistle.  Now when I have a cold,  I learn stillness.  I learn patience.  I learn that healing isn’t loud—  it’s the quiet drip of a faucet,  the steam from a cup,  the almost-silent return  of breath to balance.

instance_metrics.response: Now when I have a cold, the sky inside my skull is low and thick—  a fogged café window at dawn,  where breath and glass blur into one.  I walk through rooms like a rumor,  a draft in socks, trailing tissues like surrender flags.  My voice, once bold as a crow’s call,  now croaks in gravel,  a broken hinge confessing secrets  to the teakettle, my only confessor.  Now when I have a cold,  I remember I am temporary—  a body of paper and steam,  of sinuses like narrow alleys  where sorrow pools and drips.  I drink honeyed lemon like liquid sunlight,  but it arrives dulled, muffled,  as if grief had swallowed the taste  on its way down.  The world continues—  laughing, shouting, singing—  while I stand mute behind a mask of mucus and fatigue.  Even my thoughts snivel.  Yet in this damp hush,  there is a strange communion:  the rustle of blankets,  the drip of the tap,  the way steam curls from my cup  like a prayer that doesn’t need words.  Now when I have a cold,  I am not strong.  But I am here.  And being here,  even like this,  is its own quiet victory.

instance_metrics.response: God is the refuge of His saints, they say,  A fortress carved in everlasting stone,  Where shadows shrink at break of light and day,  And grief is hushed beneath a sighless tone. When mountains shake and oceans overflow,  When stars forget the way they once had shone,  The quiet heart still knows where to go—  Not east or west, but inward, and alone,  Yet never lonely, for in deepest night,  A voice, not heard but felt, becomes the light. instance_metrics.response: A farmer's wife, both young and gay,  Stood where the golden wheat sways,  Her laugh a spark in morning’s hush,  Her step a tune the meadow flush.  The plowman hummed a tuneless air,  The barn cats wove through clover there.  She danced in skirts of faded blue,  Chasing clouds she thought she knew—  Each one a ship, a whale, a wing,  A dream too wide for counting things.  Her hands, though soft, learned how to mend,  A broken gate, a lover’s end.  For joy is not a constant sun,  But flickers—won and lost and won.  She kissed her man at close of day,  His face worn thin by dust and clay.  She sang to chicks and calves and sky,  And taught the wind how not to sigh.  Not just a wife, nor field, nor name—  She was the flame that played the same  In harvest moon and winter’s breath,  A quiet force that conquers death.  A farmer’s wife, both young and gay—  The earth remembers how she played,  How every seed she dared to sow  Grew not just corn, but afterglow.

instance_metrics.response: Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,  Through the mist where shadows sleep.  Not with bugles, not with drumming,  But the hush before the leap.  Dew still clings to bayonet grass,  Cold as letters left unsent.  The sky, a wound that slowly pales,  Spills its light on where you went.  You dreamed of home—of cobbled lanes,  Of bread, of hands that knew your name.  Not this earth, so thick with silence,  Where even echoes dare not flame.  Rise then, not to fight, but witness:  Dawn unrolls her bloodless scroll.  The dead do not march at morning,  Yet their breath stirs in the knoll.  A lark ascends with shattered song,  Carrying what prayers it can.  The fields, once torn by iron,  Now cradle roots of common man.  So wake, not to the call of duty,  But to time’s long, mending sweep—  For peace is not the end of battle,  But the courage to remember, and weep.  Soldier, wake—the world keeps breathing,  Softly, softly, in the peeping light.  And somewhere, someone speaks your name  Into the wind, and calls it right.

Your boots are dust, your coat undone,  But still the earth remembers weight.  Each step you took, each breath you gave,  Pulses beneath the meadow’s gate. instance_metrics.response: Wake. The alarm’s shrill tongue  licks the dark from my eyes.  A yawn cracks the silence—  another brick in the wall of days.  Work. The body moves  like a clock with rusted hinges,  hands typing, lifting, reaching,  while the mind drifts through  gray corridors of thought.  Emails hum like flies  around a forgotten summer.  I am both pilot and prisoner  of this slow machine.  Home. The door sighs shut.  Shoes shed their burdens.  The kettle sings its one clear note,  and the steam writes poems  on the kitchen window.  Eat. The plate holds echoes  of flavors I don’t taste.  Chew. Swallow. Repeat.  The ritual feeds the silence.  Sleep. At last, the light bows out.  The body dissolves into sheets.  Dreams rise like moths—  fragile, flickering,  tugging at the edges  of something almost remembered.  But even they follow the chain:  wake, work, home, eat, sleep—  a lullaby for the living,  a hymn for the half-alive,  spinning in the quiet orbit  of a world that never stops  and never truly begins.

instance_metrics.response: Dawn cracks open—  a pale eye blinking behind glass.  I rise before the sun,  before thought, before breath  has time to gather itself.  The train swallows me whole,  a silver worm on steel veins.  I punch my time like a wound  into the belly of the day.  Fluorescents hum low hymns  over cubicle graves.  Fingers dance on cold keys—  prayers to the god of productivity.  Home comes like a rumor,  a whisper of couch and ceiling fan.  The microwave chimes its hollow bell.  Plastic food, warm and tasteless,  slips down the chute.  Then bed—  that soft surrender.  Limbs untwist.  Eyes sink into shadow.  The clock ticks off seconds  like a guard at an empty gate.  Wake.  Work.  Home.  Eat.  Sleep.  And again.  And again.  Not a circle—  a spiral.  Each turn tighter, quieter,  closer to the still point  where motion forgets its name,  and I, half-dreaming,  wonder if routine is just love  that forgot how to speak.

instance_metrics.response: Dawn pries open my lids with cold fingers.  The clock’s red eyes say *now, now, now*.  I peel from dreams like bark from a dead tree—  brittle, necessary.  The city stirs, a beast with smog for breath.  I join the river of feet,  each step a comma in a sentence  that never ends.  Work: a cubicle of light and lint,  where emails bloom like fungi,  where voices hum through walls—  static hymns of the useful.  Home is a door that sighs when I enter.  The fridge yawns open,  offers its pale scraps.  I chew the hours, swallow them whole.  Then sleep—  not rest, but retreat,  a folding inward like a worn flag.  The body shuts down,  but the mind still ticks:  *Wake. Work. Home. Eat. Sleep.*  Tomorrow, the alarm will sing its same sharp lie:  *This time, it matters.*  And I will believe it,  just enough to rise,  just enough to turn the wheel  in the dark.

instance_metrics.response: The dawn arrives without ceremony—  a gray light seeping through blinds,  the alarm’s electric chirp  stitching silence into motion.  I rise, not because I want to,  but because the day demands its tax.  The coffee burns, the toast blackens—  small rebellions I ignore.  Work is a room full of held breath,  keyboards clicking like crickets in dry grass.  I answer questions no one asked,  solve problems that weren’t broken.  My thoughts drift to birds,  to rivers, to the way wind bends trees—  anything that moves without permission.  Home is a dim lamp, a sinking couch,  the television murmuring to itself.  I eat what’s easy, what requires  no ceremony, no joy.  Then bed—  where the spine uncoils,  where the eyes close  but the mind stays open,  pacing the halls of tomorrow’s list.  Wake. Work. Home. Eat. Sleep.  Each word a stone in a cairn  marking a path I didn’t choose,  yet walk as if it leads somewhere.  And maybe it does—  not to glory, not to peace,  but to the quiet dignity  of showing up,  again and again,  in a world that rarely looks back.

instance_metrics.response: Dawn arrives like a habit—  unasked, inevitable.  I peel back sleep as one sheds skin,  step into the suit of the day.  The bus exhales diesel prayers,  carrying ghosts with earbuds and plans.  Work: a fluorescent hive,  where time dissolves in spreadsheets,  where voices orbit polite lies,  and the soul files itself under *pending*.  Home—four walls that remember  every sigh, every silence stretched thin.  The fridge hums a lullaby of leftovers.  I chew without tasting,  swallow the hours whole.  Then sleep, not as refuge,  but as reset, as surrender,  the body folding into dark like a letter  never meant to be read.  And tomorrow, the alarm will whisper  with the voice of yesterday:  *Again. Again.*  Not a life refused,  but a life lived in parentheses—  a breath held between  wake, work, home, eat, sleep—  cycling like seasons no one named,  each turn quieter,  each step softer,  until the pattern becomes the pulse,  and the pulse,  almost,  a kind of prayer.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, the wind hums low,  A dirge for the lost, a song for the slow.  Each mile a memory, cracked and worn,  Pavement whispering of hearts forlorn.  No signs to guide, no map to hold,  Just dust-stained dreams and stories untold.  Trucks groan past like mourners in line,  Their headlights cutting through bruised twilight’s sign.  Here, the weary trade their names for silence,  Barter hope at every traffic violence.  A woman counts stars in the exhaust’s haze,  Her child asleep in the cold neon blaze.  At rest stops, shadows sip bitter coffee,  Laughing too loud at the dark’s soft reproof.  They know the weight of unspoken grief—  A suitcase chained to the soul’s brief lease.  The asphalt stretches, a serpent uncoiling,  Promising distance, but never unspoiling.  For every exit says *Almost there*,  Yet delivers only another stair  Up the mountain of almost, the valley of near,  Where love once bloomed, now fossilized fear.  But sometimes—oh, sometimes—a sparrow takes flight  Above the din, into mercy’s soft light.  And for a breath, the highway forgives,  And sorrow drives with quieter wheels.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, where thunder sleeps in tires,  roads unravel like sutures pulled from old wounds.  No beginning, no end—only the hum  of engines dragging ghosts through fog-bound dawns.  Here, the asphalt breathes in cracked syllables,  reciting names of those who vanished mid-sentence.  A glove left on gravel. A photo half-burnt.  The radio plays a song no one remembers choosing.  Travelers trade glances in mirrorless mirrors,  each face a blurred country they’ve been exiled from.  One lights a cigarette with a trembling alibi.  Another writes letters the wind eats as she speaks.  This is not a place of arrival, but of passing—  bodies leaning into the pull of unseen gravity.  Even the streetlights bow their heads,  dripping yellow tears on shoulders of shadow.  Yet somewhere beneath the tar, roots stir.  Somewhere, a seed cracks open in the dark,  not despite the weight, but because of it.  And a single green whisper dares the night:  *You are not the wreckage. You are the road’s slow healing.*

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, where silence wears tires,  the earth remembers every name erased by rain.  No billboards shout here, only the hush  of telephone poles humming forgotten vows.  This is the route the broken take—  not in cars, but in breaths held too long,  in footsteps that echo like distant horns  through tunnels where light forgets to live.  A suitcase sags at mile thirty-two,  its owner dissolved into the diesel mist.  Another walks with a suitcase made of smoke,  carrying apologies that never reached their address.  Trucks roll by with murals of vanished towns—  a mural of a child waving from a porch  that was paved over before dawn.  The road drinks sorrow like gasoline,  burns it into momentum, into distance,  into the lie that going is the same as healing.  But listen—beneath the grind of wheels,  a pulse: small, stubborn, rising.  Dandelions split the asphalt’s skin.  A crow sings a note not in the scale of grief.  And somewhere, a hitchhiker lifts her hand—  not to stop, but to feel the wind  finally move *through* her, not just past.  At the highways of woes,  even the weight of years cannot kill  the quiet will to keep crossing.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, the stars are smog-thick and low,  hanging like broken signals above the endless row  of cracked dividers and rusted guardrails  where memory veers off in forgotten trails.  No exit signs for regret or repair,  just the flicker of motels in the greasy air—  rooms rented by the hour, by the ache, by the lie,  where shadows rehearse how to say goodbye.  Here, the wind carries fragments: a lullaby hummed,  a wedding band tossed where the overpass numbed  the pulse of the river below. It still flows,  though choked with rust and unanswered letters.  Trucks thunder past with cargo of silence—  crates sealed shut with grief’s old violence.  No manifest, no destination clear,  only the rhythm of wheels that refuse to hear.  A woman stands barefoot on the shoulder’s edge,  her suitcase full of unsent confessions.  She whispers to the dark, “I was never the storm—  just the house that weathered every form.”  And the road does not answer. It only extends,  a scar across the land that never mends,  yet somehow—beneath tire tracks and time—  pushes up violets in rhythm and rhyme.  For even here, where sorrow runs deep,  the heart learns to walk, to breathe, to keep  one foot before the other, not toward end,  but into the fragile grace of beginning again.

instance_metrics.response: At the highways of woes, the sky forgets its name,  and the clouds drag their feet like tired witnesses. A shoe lies abandoned near mile marker nine,  laced with the memory of a step too heavy to finish.  Somewhere, a radio murmurs a hymn  to the god of rearview mirrors—  the one who lets you look, but never return.  Grief drives a yellow truck with no headlights,  trusting the dark to know the way. instance_metrics.response: The breezes waved the silver grass,  a hush across the waking plain,  as dawn unrolled its quiet glass  and brushed the shadows off the plain.  Each blade a thread of whispered light,  a tapestry the wind could read,  stitching the margins of the night  into the margin of the mead.  No bird dared break the fragile air,  yet something hummed beneath the hush—  a memory the earth would bear  of root and rain and ancient rush.  The silver grass did not reply,  but bowed as if to greet the gone—  the deer that leapt, the falcon’s cry,  the footfall lost, the lover’s dawn.  And I, who stood too still to name  the ache that bent my spine like reeds,  felt time dissolve into the frame  of root and dust and wind and seeds.  For in that sway, so frail, so vast,  the world confessed its softest law:  all things that rise are born to pass,  yet linger in the breath of straw.  The breezes waved the silver grass—  and I became the hush they passed.

instance_metrics.response: The breezes waved the silver grass, a ripple through the drowsy field, where moonlight pooled in cool morass and time lay still, the world unsealed. No sun to scorch, no cry of hawk, just hush and shimmer, stem to stem, as if the night had paused to talk in whispers only roots could comprehend. Each blade a filament of ghost-light, trembling with a secret told not in words, but in the slight lean of stalk to shadowed stalk—old stories passed in silent trust. The earth exhaled a silver breath, and I, a stranger on the rim, felt something loosen—close to death, yet thrumming with a newborn hymn. Was I the wind? Or was I weed, born of dust and sky and dew? Did I belong to this quiet mead, or was I merely passing through? The grass kept swaying, never asking, never judging, never still. In its dance, no past, no tasking—only presence, cool and clear. And for a breath, I swayed as well, unmoored, unheld, unchained, unfurled— a man become a silver bell, rung once into the listening world. Then the breeze moved on, and I stood plain, two feet on soil, heart full of sky— but something in me stayed to sway beneath the vast and star-strewn eye.

instance_metrics.response: The breezes waved the silver grass, a slow exhalation of the hill, where twilight pooled in shadows vast and silence bent to listen still. The silver grass did not resist, but bowed as centuries had done, to every wind, both fierce and kiss, beneath the turning moon and sun. And in that sway, a truth took hold—not loud, not bright, but soft and long: that strength is not in standing bold, but in the grace to bend, belong. To be the field, not just the flower, to yield without a cry or crack, to meet the storm with quiet power, then rise when all the gales move back. instance_metrics.response: I respect the hands that shape a different prayer,  the hushed invocations whispered into dawn,  the call to worship rising on the air  in tongues I do not speak, yet still am drawn.  I respect the skin that holds the sun’s deep kiss,  the spectrum worn like robes no hatred sewed,  the history mapped in every shade of this—  a world in motion, beautifully imbued.  I respect the creed that walks a separate road,  bearing light through valleys shadowed by doubt,  the quiet strength in every sacred code,  the courage faith can summon, fierce and stout.  Not mine, yet human—anchored in the same  need to belong, to hope, to speak a name  into the void and feel it answered back.  We build our altars where the silence cracks.  To respect is not to yield, nor to concede,  but to stand beside, and say: *I see your flame.*  No fence of fear, no wall of pride or greed—  just space enough for each to speak their name.  The world is wide, and wisdom walks in many shoes.  I bow not to your god, but to your truth.  And in that bow, a bridge begins to rise—  not built of stone, but mutual surprise.

instance_metrics.response: I respect the quiet hymn beneath his breath,  the way he folds his hands before he eats,  the symbols stitched into the fabric of his death,  the rhythm of the prayers beneath his feet.  I respect the color of his morning sky,  the gold and brown that cradle his mother’s eyes,  the stories passed where generations lie,  the language sung in lullabies and cries.  I respect the path he walks, though not my own,  the compass of his soul, the creed he keeps,  the seeds of faith in stony ground he’s sown,  the vigil through the nights his spirit weeps.  Not to convert, nor claim my way is true,  but to acknowledge: *I walk beside, not over you.*  For dignity is not a single thread,  but woven wide by every voice, every head  that lifts in search of meaning, light, or peace—  each different, yet all longing to release  the same soft breath that says: *I am, I care,  I hope, I hurt, I’m here, I’m everywhere.*  To honor you is not to wear your shoes,  but to let your footsteps fall without excuse.  The world grows larger when we kneel and rise  not in unison—but with mirrored eyes.

I respect the colors time cannot repeal,  the lineage of land, the shadow and the depth  of stories etched in faces not my own,  the weight of history carried in a name,  the silent pride in blood and bone and stone,  the fire that flickers, never quite the same.  I respect the creed that asks for no disguise,  the courage to believe when mocked or scorned,  the faith that lifts a child’s bewildered eyes  to something vast, however it’s adorned.  Not with pity, nor with distant grace,  but standing shoulder-close in shared terrain—  each different, yet we meet within this space,  where dignity is not bestowed, but claimed.  For respect is not agreement, nor a door  that opens only if you speak my tongue.  It’s letting you believe, and asking no more  than room enough for all of us to belong.  The world is wide with wonder, wide with woe—  and wider still when we let others grow.

instance_metrics.response: Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,  Through the smoke and silent dew,  Where the breath of dawn lies sleeping  On the faces, pale and true.  Not with trumpets, not with thunder,  But a whisper, soft and deep—  Like a mother’s hand to wonder,  Calling weary eyes from sleep.  You, who dreamed of fields unbroken,  Of a girl with chestnut hair,  Of a cottage, warm, unspoken,  And the peace that lingers there—  Rise. The world still turns in shadow,  With its wounds and silent cries.  Not for glory, not for marrow,  But for truth beneath gray skies.  Your rifle gleams with morning's tracing,  Your boots are caked with yesterday.  No fanfare marks this grim embracing—  Only duty charts the way.  Yet in your chest, a quiet ember:  Love that will not be undone.  Though the earth may split and remember,  You rise not to take, but shun.  So wake, not to conquest’s measure,  But to guard what light remains—  In the hush before all seizure,  In the blood that blooms like rains.  Soldier, wake—the day is peeping.  Will you answer? Will you stay?  Even now, the world is weeping  For the price it dares not pay.

instance_metrics.response: There is a law which guarantees  the tide will slip from stubborn stone,  that roots will split the concrete’s claim,  and seeds will crack what we call home.  No statue stands without its flaw,  no border drawn that shadows spare—  the moon still pulls regardless, raw,  and night dissolves the official air.  There is a law not signed in ink,  but woven through the thrush’s throat,  a pulse beneath the city’s blink,  a verdict time cannot revoke.  It hums where children draw their maps  with rivers looping through erased lines,  in hands that shape, rebuild, collapse—  in every act that quietly defies.  No tyrant holds the sun’s return,  no ledger lists the breath of wheat.  The world revives its old concerns:  the soil remembers what is sweet.  So when they preach of order, stay  attuned to quieter decrees—  the law that guarantees the clay  will rise and wear the crown of trees.

instance_metrics.response: There is a law which guarantees  the hush between the clock’s harsh beats,  the pause before the answer fits,  the breath before the sentence breaks.  Not written, but it lives in hands—  in bread torn warm, in worn front steps  where neighbors meet without demands,  in how the light forgives the cracks.  It guards the quiet, stubborn spark  that hums beneath a lullaby,  the grammar of the evening dark,  the way we learn to say good-bye.  There is a law no court can hold—  it thrives in glances, half-concealed,  in stories passed but never sold,  in fields where no one signed the deed.  It stirs in laughter, low and deep,  in gardens where the fences lean,  in promises the broken keep,  in what the map forgot to name.  No force can halt the slow return—  the tides of root, of rain, of rhyme—  the world still burns with its own yearn,  outlasting every line of time.  So let them carve their rules in stone—  this quiet law will still remain:  that love, though nameless, stands alone  and blooms in spite of every chain.

instance_metrics.response: There is a law which guarantees  the sky will outlast every tower,  that silence follows loudest vows,  and even fire needs its hour.  Not etched in stone, nor signed in blood,  but whispered where the willows bend—  the truth that all must yield to flood,  the wound that time won’t quite amend.  It hums beneath the courthouse dome,  in cracks where frost has done its work,  in every seed that finds a home  in ruins left to dust and murk.  No king can tax the rising dew,  no army march against the bloom  that splits the road in two.  This law does not proclaim or shout—  it lives in hands that plant in vain,  in songs the exiled carry out,  in rain that falls on field and chain.  It is the weight of unmarked graves,  the pull behind the migrant’s tread,  the force no ledger ever saves,  the breath that rises from the dead.  So when the world insists on wall,  on order carved with iron creed,  remember: green will overgrow  the law of might, the law of need.  There is a law—soft, deep, and slow—  that guarantees the world will grow  not toward the hammer, but the seed,  not toward power, but the plea  of every root that dares to breathe:  *We rise, though crushed, though out of sight.  We are the law that conquers light.*
